questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman from Jaipur presents with multiple episodes of syncope over the last 3 months, often occurring at rest or during sleep. She denies chest pain or palpitations. Her father died suddenly in his early 40s. Physical examination and laboratory tests, including troponins and electrolytes, are unremarkable. Echocardiography shows a structurally normal heart. Her ECG is shown below.

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 45-year-old male shipyard worker presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath over the past 6 months. He denies chest pain or cough and has never smoked. He worked in ship insulation for 20 years. On examination, bibasal fine crackles are heard. Chest X-ray is shown below. 

 

 

Pulmonary function testing (PFT) shows:

  • FEV₁: 65%
  • FVC: 60%
  • FEV₁/FVC: 84%
  • DLCO: 48%

These lesions in the CXR are precursors to which of the following malignancies?

A 54-year-old woman from Delhi with long-standing poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with swelling of the face, proximal muscle weakness, and easy bruising. Examination reveals central obesity, purple striae, and facial plethora. BP is 164/100 mmHg. Her serum cortisol is elevated. Pituitary MRI is normal, and a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows <50% suppression of ACTH levels.

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 28-year-old man from Bengaluru presents with progressive stiffness in both legs for the past 10 years, which has gradually worsened his walking. He denies any sensory loss, coordination issues, or bladder symptoms. His older brother has a similar walking difficulty. On examination, there is bilateral lower limb spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar responses, with no cerebellar or sensory deficits. MRI of the brain and spine is reported as normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 66-year-old man from Ahmedabad presents with progressive fatigue and unintended weight loss over the past 3 months. Examination reveals massive splenomegaly.


Labs show:

  • Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
  • WBC: 3,200/mm³
  • Platelets: 65,000/mm³

     

Peripheral smear is shown below. Bone marrow biopsy shows 3+ fibrosis. Molecular testing is positive for JAK2 V617F mutation.

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 26-year-old woman from Hyderabad presents with facial puffiness, cola-colored urine, and elevated blood pressure. Lab investigations show:

  • Proteinuria: 2.8 g/day
  • Serum creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL
  • ANA: Positive (1:640, homogenous)
  • Anti-dsDNA: Positive

Renal biopsy is shown below. 

 

 

What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Cyclophosphamide + high dose prednisolone

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents with complaints of pain and stiffness in the fingers, along with chronic heel pain and morning stiffness. On physical examination, he has the following finding but no visible skin lesions. An X-ray of the hand is shown. Laboratory investigations reveal that he is HLA-B27 positive and rheumatoid factor (RF) negative.

 

 

Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man with cirrhosis presents with confusion and altered sleep-wake cycle. He is disoriented with the following finding. Doppler ultrasound reveals hepatofugal flow in the portal vein. What is the most appropriate initial management?

A 22-year-old woman from rural Bihar presents with 3 weeks of low-grade fever, unintentional weight loss, and progressive weakness. On examination, she has massive splenomegaly and pallor. Lab tests reveal pancytopenia, and the rK39 rapid diagnostic test is positive. What is the treatment of choice for this patient’s condition?

A 66-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 28% presents with persistent NYHA Class III symptoms despite being on optimal guideline-directed medical therapy, including a carvedilol, ramipril, spironolactone, and dapagliflozin. His ECG shown below.

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 30-year-old woman presents with left lower limb pain and swelling. Doppler confirms DVT. Coagulation profile shows a prolonged aPTT and mixing study fails to correct aPTT. She is currently not on any drugs. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old man with HIV infection (CD4 = 72 cells/mm³) and miliary tuberculosis was started on antitubercular therapy (ATT) and antiretroviral therapy (ART). Three weeks later, he presents with fever, worsening cough, and new cervical lymphadenopathy. Repeat CB-NAAT from sputum is negative. What is the most likely cause of his clinical worsening?

A 34-year-old man presents with a history of kidney stones, constipation, and fatigue. On examination. Lab results show:

  • Serum calcium: 12.5 mg/dL
  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH): Elevated

  • Serum prolactin: Normal

     

 

 

He had surgery for a pheochromocytoma one year ago. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. On examination, he has pale conjunctivae.
Lab results:

  • Hemoglobin: 7.8 g/dL
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 68 fL
  • Serum ferritin: 8ng/mL

Upper GI endoscopy reveals multiple angioectasias in the proximal duodenum. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Endoscopic argon plasma coagulation

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent pneumonia since childhood, digital clubbing, and infertility. He also reports persistent nasal congestion and chronic cough. On examination, there are bilateral coarse crepitations. Chest CT reveals central bronchiectasis and mucous plugging. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents with progressive headache and vomiting for the past 2 weeks. He has no fever, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. MRI of the brain is shown below. 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, arthritis, photosensitivity, and oral ulcers. Urine shows proteinuria and RBC casts. C3/C4 is low. What antibody is most specific for her disease?

choices.text: Continue NSAIDs at a lower dose

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic tophaceous gout and stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) presents with severe joint pain and visible tophi. His serum uric acid is 10.5 mg/dL. He previously developed a rash with allopurinol and had gastrointestinal side effects with febuxostat. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 60-year-old man with sepsis due to pneumonia is intubated in the ICU. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following:

  • pH: 7.11
  • PaCO₂: 58 mmHg
  • HCO₃⁻: 19 mEq/L

What is the most likely primary acid-base disorder?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A 55-year-old ICU patient has been receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for the past 10 days. He now develops confusion and seizures. Laboratory results are as follows:

  • Magnesium: 0.7 mg/dL 
  • Calcium: 6.5 mg/dL 
  • Potassium: 2.9 mEq/L 
  • Phosphate: 1.0 mg/dL 

What is the most likely cause of his neurological symptoms?

choices.text: Urgent pericardiocentesis with CT imaging follow-up
Immediate surgical consult for suspected aortic dissection
Start IV norepinephrine and defer intervention
Administer IV thrombolytics for possible pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and smoking presents with acute dyspnea, chest pain and hypotension. BP is 80/60 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm and has jugular venous distention. ECG and CXR are shown below. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Immediate surgical consult for suspected aortic dissection

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with episodes of confusion, palpitations, and sweating, which consistently resolve after meals. During a supervised 72-hour fast, she develops hypoglycemia (glucose 42 mg/dL) accompanied by elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution: Ans. C) CT abdomen with contrast

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with persistent fever, weight loss, and a new diastolic murmur. Transthoracic echocardiography image is shown below. Blood cultures taken over 72 hours are negative despite appropriate incubation.

 

 

What is the best next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Order Brucella and Coxiella serology

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness for 10 days. MRI brain is shown below. 

 

 

CSF analysis reveals:

  • Predominant lymphocytes
  • Low glucose
  • High protein

What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 64-year-old retired teacher from Amritsar presents with progressively worsening fatigue, loss of appetite, and dull lower back pain for 3 months. His family reports recent episodes of confusion. On evaluation, his creatinine is 3.1 mg/dL, hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL, and serum calcium 11.6 mg/dL. Urine dipstick is negative for protein, but serum total protein is elevated. What is the most likely cause of his kidney dysfunction?

A 45-year-old man with a history of acromegaly underwent transsphenoidal resection 9 months ago. He continues to have symptoms such as coarse facial features and hand enlargement. Laboratory tests show persistently elevated IGF-1 and GH levels. MRI sella reveals a small residual pituitary tumor. He is already on monthly octreotide LAR 30 mg. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform extended red cell antigen matching

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with chronic anemia (Hb 7.2 g/dL) due to myelodysplastic syndrome receives a packed RBC transfusion. Ten days later, he presents with jaundice, dark urine, and Hb drop to 5.8 g/dL. Coombs test is positive. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Perform extended red cell antigen matching

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man from Hyderabad with a known history of severe COPD is intubated in the ICU due to type 2 respiratory failure. He is being ventilated on volume assist-control mode. A few hours later, the nurse notes he has become agitated and tachypneic with visible accessory muscle use. Ventilator image is shown below.

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Add sedation + neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: A 36-year-old man from Nagpur with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with severe epigastric pain and multiple episodes of vomiting for 2 days. Serum amylase is 980 U/L. He is started on IV fluids and kept NPO. On Day 3, his BP 98/60 mmHg, HR 112/min, has a creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL, and O₂ saturation of 88% on room air. A contrast-enhanced CT scan shows peripancreatic fat stranding and fluid collections. What is the most accurate diagnosis regarding his condition?

A 64-year-old man from Lucknow with known stage 3 chronic kidney disease presents with a sudden increase in serum creatinine from 1.9 mg/dL to 4.8 mg/dL over 5 days. He was recently started on lisinopril, furosemide, and indomethacin for hypertension and knee arthritis. His BP is 100/70 mmHg, and urinalysis reveals bland urine sediment (no casts, protein, or cells). What is the most likely mechanism for his acute kidney injury?

choices.text: Oral aspirin, ticagrelor, and transfer for PCI
IV streptokinase, aspirin, clopidogrel, and transfer
IV heparin, nitroglycerin, and ICU admission
Oral metoprolol, aspirin, and angiography within 48 hours

questions.text: A 62-year-old male from Mumbai presents with central chest pain for 4 hours, radiating to the left arm, associated with diaphoresis and dyspnea. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and smoking (20 pack-years). BP is 150/90 mmHg, pulse 92/min. The ECG is shown below. Troponin T is 1.8 ng/mL (normal < 0.04). The nearest PCI-capable center is 4 hours away. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) IV streptokinase, aspirin, clopidogrel, and transfer

choices.text: Start amiodarone and plan for electrical cardioversion

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with palpitations, fatigue, and occasional syncope for 2 weeks. She has a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. The ECG is shown below. Her TSH is 4.2 mIU/L, and serum potassium is 3.8 mmol/L. Echocardiography reveals an enlarged left atrium. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Start metoprolol and apixaban

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with dyspnea and peripheral edema. Examination reveals S3 and S4 with hepatomegaly and Jugular venous distension. ECG and Echocardiogram is shown below. EF is 50%. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male from Uttar Pradesh presents with cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss for 3 months. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis (treated) 5 years ago. Sputum AFB and CB-NAAT for M. tuberculosis is negative, and the CT scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Start with PEEP of 5 cm H2O and adjust tidal volume to 6 mL/kg

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is admitted to the ICU with severe dyspnea and hypoxemia. She has a history of COPD and was having fever and increased cough for the last 3 days. ABG shows pH 7.28, PaCO2 60 mmHg, PaO2 50 mmHg. Patient was intubated and ventilated in view of severe hypoxemia and the CXR is shown below. Which of the following is not recommended as the next step?

A 45-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea and dry cough for 6 months. He works as a construction worker and smokes 10 cigarettes daily. HRCT chest is shown below. PFTs show restrictive pattern with DLCO 40% predicted. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Refer for lung biopsy

questions.text: A 40-year-old female from Bihar presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance for 6 months. She has a history of delivery complicated by hypotension that required multiple blood transfusions 5 years ago. TSH is 15 mIU/L, free T4 0.6 ng/dL, and prolactin is low. The thyroid ultrasound reveals a small, hypoechoic gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presents with polyuria for 2 months. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. HbA1c is 8.2%, fasting glucose 180 mg/dL, and serum potassium 3.6 mmol/L. Fundoscopy is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Initiate metformin and lisinopril

choices.text: Start oral contraceptive pills and metformin
Initiate clomiphene citrate and lifestyle modification
Begin letrozole and weight loss counseling

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with irregular menses, hirsutism, and weight gain for 2 years. BMI is 30 kg/m², and BP is 140/90 mmHg. Serum testosterone is 80 ng/dL (normal 15-70), and fasting glucose is 110 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Start oral contraceptive pills and metformin

questions.text: A 30-year-old male from Bihar presents with focal seizures followed by GTCS. EEG shows focal temporal lobe epileptiform discharges. MRI brain is shown below. What is the most appropriate management after adding corticosteroids?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Start levetiracetam and albendazole

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with progressive memory loss and confusion for 18 months. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes. MMSE score is 22/30. CT brain shows diffuse cortical atrophy and CSF analysis shows low Aβ42 and elevated tau. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Administer IV alteplase and start aspirin
Perform CT Angiography and CT Perfusion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with acute-onset weakness in the right arm and leg for 5 hours. She has a history of smoking and oral contraceptive use. BP is 160/95 mmHg, and CT brain is shown below. NIHSS score is 8. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Perform CT Angiography Only.

questions.text: A 70-year-old retired teacher is evaluated after routine blood tests revealed a high total protein level. He feels well and reports no fatigue, weight loss, or bone pain. Laboratory tests show creatinine 1.0 mg/dL, calcium 9.8 mg/dL, albumin 4.1 g/dL, and hemoglobin 12.8 g/dL. Protein electrophoresis is shown below and a bone marrow biopsy showing 15% clonal plasma cells. What is the next best step in management?

A 55-year-old female presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and night sweats for 3 months. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step?

A 50-year-old male presents with jaundice, weight loss, and epigastric pain for 2 months. He has a history of chronic alcohol use. Serum bilirubin is 15.8 mg/dL, ALP 1280 IU/L, AST 120 U/L, and ALT 80 U/L. CT scan shows a pancreatic head mass with dilated CBD. What is the most appropriate next step?

A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, dark urine, and right upper quadrant pain for 3 weeks. He has a history of blood transfusion 20 years ago. Serum bilirubin is 3.2 mg/dL, ALT 250 U/L, and HCV RNA is positive. What is the most appropriate management?

A 35-year-old female presents with joint pain, morning stiffness, and fatigue for 6 months. She has a history of dry eyes and mouth. RF is positive, anti-CCP is elevated, and ESR is 60 mm/hr. Hand X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Initiate methotrexate and folic acid

choices.text: Initiate sulfasalazine and high dose Ibuprofen.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with low back pain and stiffness for 1 year, worse in the mornings. He has tried Naproxen without much benefit. He has a history of recurrent uveitis and ESR is 45 mm/hr. Pelvic X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Prescribe adalimumab and physical therapy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with edema, hypertension, and hematuria for 2 months. He has a history of diabetes and smoking. Serum creatinine is 2.8 mg/dL, and urine protein is 3.5 g/day. Renal biopsy and immunofluresence is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old female presents with fatigue, hypertension, and worsening renal function for 3 months. Serum creatinine is 3.2 mg/dL, and potassium is 5.8 mmol/L. Renal ultrasound reveals bilateral renal artery stenosis. She is on amlodipine and metformin. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Perform renal artery angioplasty

questions.text: A 58-year-old man from Maharashtra presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, and easy fatigability over 3 months. On examination, he has a tapping apex beat, loud S1, and a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation at the apex. There is also a palpable P2 and mild pedal edema. ECG is shown below. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Transthoracic echocardiography with Doppler

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with worsening breathlessness, orthopnea, and mild ankle edema. He is NYHA class III. Echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 35%. He is already on bisoprolol and furosemide has been started for reducing congestion. Blood pressure is 102/66 mmHg, creatinine 1.4 mg/dL, and potassium is 5.2 mEq/L. CXR is shown below. What is the best additional drug as of now that can improve long-term outcomes in this case?

A 36-year-old woman from Lucknow presents with progressive weakness of the right arm and leg, facial numbness, and hoarseness of voice. She also reports occasional vertigo and hiccups. Examination shows decreased pain and temperature sensation on the left limbs and right face, with right-sided Horner's syndrome. MRI brain is shown below. What is the most likely vascular territory involved?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of productive cough, dyspnea, intermittent fever, night sweats, and a 9-kg weight loss. On examination, she has diffuse crackles and expiratory wheeze. 
Labs: Eosinophil count in peripheral blood = 5240/mm³, and BAL fluid shows, 74% eosinophils. Aspergillus serology and ANCA are Negative. CXR is done and it is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old woman with asthma presents with refractory symptoms and thick brown sputum. She has no fever. Total IgE is 2200 IU/mL, absolute eosinophil count is 1200/mm³. CXR is shown below. What is the best next step?

A 60-year-old male presents with gradual-onset breathlessness, dry cough, and fatigue for the past 6 months. He worked in a granite polishing unit for 30 years. On examination, clubbing and fine bibasal inspiratory crepitations are noted. Chest X-ray is shown below. PFT shows a restrictive pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman from Jharkhand presents with 3 weeks of low-grade fever, dry cough, and weight loss. She also has irregular menses. CXR is shown. Mantoux is negative. BAL fluid CB-NAAT is negative and CD4 count is elevated. Endometrial biopsy is positive for granulomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old hypertensive woman presents with headache, vomiting, and transient visual blurring for 2 days. BP is 220/120 mmHg. Fundoscopy shows grade III hypertensive changes. MRI brain is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted with fever, rash, and polyarthralgia. He has mild hepatomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy. Labs: WBC 24,000/mm³ with 85% neutrophils, ESR 90 mm/h, ferritin 9500 ng/mL. ANA and RF are negative. Work up for tropical infections are negative as well. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Urgent Needle Decompression in the 5th ICS in the MAL.
Urgent Needle Decompression in the 2nd ICS in the MCL.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. He is tall and thin. On auscultation, breath sounds are absent on the right side with hyper-resonant note on percussion. CXR is shown below. Vitals: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 90/min, SpO₂ 98% and no jugular venous distension. What is the next step?

A 34-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. He is a known alcoholic. On exam: HR 108/min, BP 90/60 mmHg, RR 28/min, and SpO₂ 91%. Labs show amylase 560 U/L, lipase 720 U/L. Chest X-ray shows a left pleural effusion. What is the most likely ABG finding?
questions.solution: Ans. A) pH 7.3, HCO3- 14, Anion gap 25, PaCO2 25

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with menorrhagia, petechiae, and fatigue presents for evaluation. CBC: Hb 14 g/dL, WBC 8,500, Platelets 12,000. PT/INR normal. Peripheral smear is shown below. No hepatosplenomegaly. Direct Coombs test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 32-year-old man from Uttar Pradesh presents with prolonged fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly. CBC shows pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents with facial puffiness and urine that appears as shown below for 3 day. She also reports multiple joint pains for the last 2 months. BP is 156/94 mmHg. Urinalysis shows RBC casts, 3+ proteinuria. C3 is low. What is the most likely diagnosis given the clinical scenario?

A 43-year-old male alcoholic presents with hematemesis and melena. BP is 90/60 mmHg, HR 110/min. NG tube reveals bright red blood. After resuscitation, upper GI endoscopy is done and the findings are shown. What is the next best step in management?

A 26-year-old woman with known SLE presents with acute confusion, hallucinations, and behavioral changes for 2 days. She is afebrile, oriented only to person, and has no focal deficits. CT brain is normal. CSF shows 4 cells/mm³, mildly raised protein, and normal glucose. MRI shows bilateral frontal subcortical T2 hyperintensities. ANA is positive (1:320). Which of the following is likely to be related to the patient's presentation?

A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with worsening headache, vomiting, and new-onset diplopia. She is febrile and drowsy. Fundoscopy shows papilledema. A contrast-enhanced MRI is shown below. What is the next best step?

A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a persistent cough and occasional haemoptysis. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking. An urgent chest x-ray is reported as being normal. In patients who are subsequently diagnosed with lung cancer, what percentage of recent chest x-rays were reported as normal?

A 29-year-old woman presents with easy bruising, prolonged menstrual bleeding, and epistaxis since childhood. Her brother has similar symptoms. On examination, petechiae are present over both legs. Platelet count is mildly low. Peripheral smear is shown. PT and aPTT are normal. Platelet aggregation is absent with ristocetin. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with increasing fatigue and facial puffiness. BP is 160/100 mmHg. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. Fundus shows cotton wool spots and microaneurysms. Which among the following would not be recommended?

A 26-year-old woman presents with reddish urine. Laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, elevated serum LDH, and unconjugated bilirubin. A peripheral smear reveals pancytopenia. Flow cytometry is done and shown Which of the following is unlikely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Positive Direct Coombs Test (DCT)

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a BMI 34 kg/m² presents for evaluation of her liver function tests, which reveal elevated levels of AST and ALT. She has no history of alcohol use, viral hepatitis, or significant liver disease. After lifestyle modifications and weight loss attempts, her healthcare provider discusses pharmacotherapy options for her condition. Which of the following medications is FDA-approved for the management of her condition?

A 67-year-old man presents with chronic, progressive fatigue, unintentional weight loss, left-sided abdominal discomfort, and left shoulder pain. On physical examination, nontender bilateral axillary and right-sided inguinal lymphadenopathy are noted, along with hepatosplenomegaly. A peripheral smear is done and shown below. Which of the following is the most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with this condition?

A 68-year-old male presents with acute kidney injury (AKI) 7 days after undergoing coronary angiography (CAG). Laboratory tests reveal elevated creatinine levels and hypocomplementemia. A renal biopsy is done and shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?

A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice. Serologic testing shows:

 

 

What does this serologic profile indicate?
questions.solution: Ans. A) HBV and HDV coinfection
